entry.et: Middle English vewe, vyewe, from Anglo-French, from feminine of veu, viewe, past participle of veer to see, from Latin vidēre wit

def.dt: :extent or range of vision :sight tried to keep the ship in view sat high in the bleachers to get a good view
:the act of seeing or examining :inspection
:survey a view of English literature
:a mode or manner of looking at or regarding something
:an opinion or judgment colored by the feeling or bias of its holder in my view the plan will fail
:scene prospect the lovely view from the balcony
:the foreseeable future no hope in view
:a pictorial representation
:in regard to :in consideration of
:open to public inspection :on exhibition
:with the object of studied hard with a view to getting an A
:to look at attentively :scrutinize observe view an exhibit
:see watch
:to look on in a particular light :regard doesn't view himself as a rebel
:to survey or examine mentally :consider view all sides of a question

dt.un: used in fox hunting on seeing a fox break cover

def.dt: :a view from a high angle as if seen by a bird in flight
:an overall or cursory look at something
:point of view an alien eye view
:field 5
:an approach to a problem or situation that emphasizes long-range factors
:a cable television service by which customers can order access to a particular broadcast for a fee
:a position or perspective from which something is considered or evaluated :standpoint
city W California NW of San Jose pop 70,708
